brief_description: the human protease genes required for influenza virus replication were determined and validated using RNA interference approaches. The genes validated as critical for influenza virus replication were ADAMTS7, CPE, DPP3, MST1, and PRSS12, and pathway analysis showed these genes were in global host cell pathways governing inflammation (NF-kB), cAMP/calcium signaling (CRE/CREB), and apoptosis.
brief_title: MicroRNA Regulation of Human Protease Genes
description: the human protease genes required for influenza virus replication were determined and validated using RNA interference approaches. The genes validated as critical for influenza virus replication were ADAMTS7, CPE, DPP3, MST1, and PRSS12, and pathway analysis showed these genes were in global host cell pathways governing inflammation (NF-kB), cAMP/calcium signaling (CRE/CREB), and apoptosis.
hypothesis: explore host genes and microRNAs important for influenza replication providing potential new targets for disease intervention strategies
intervention_agent: A/WSN/33 and A/New Caledonia/20/99 H1N1 influenza virus
objectives: Identify host genes and microRNAs important for influenza replication providing potential new targets for disease intervention strategies
official_title: MicroRNA Regulation of Human Protease Genes Essential for Influenza Virus Replication

arm.description: A549 cells (ATCC CCL-185) were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) (HyClone, Logan, UT) containing 5% heat-inactivated FBS (HyClone, Logan, UT). Cells were frozen in 10% DMSO and 90% FBS to create one stock of a single cell passage that was used for the entire screen.
arm.name: VM12-PO-Arm

personnel.organization: Department of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia
personnel.site_name: Department of Infectious Diseases, University of Georgia

pubmed.title: MicroRNA regulation of human protease genes essential for influenza virus replication.

program.program_name: NIAID Centers of Excellence for Influenza Research and Surveillance (CEIRS)
